item.title: Listening to Cecilia Todd – Acidito
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Upon watching an Instagram Reel by David Asher Brown on Venezuelan merengue and its unique 5/8 rhythm, I…
item.content:encoded:
Upon watching an Instagram Reel by David Asher Brown on Venezuelan merengue and its unique 5/8 rhythm, I decided to explore one of the genre’s most renowned compositions, Acidito. The song was composed by Adelis Fréitez and has been popularized by several singers and bands.

Cecilia Todd Vallenilla is a well-known Venezuelan musician, recognized for her performances of traditional Venezuelan folk music. She is especially skilled in playing the cuatro, which she uses to accompany herself in performances both within Venezuela and abroad.

Upon close listening, it became clear that the 5/8 rhythm of Venezuelan merengue, as described by David Asher Brown, feels natural without any apparent sense of strain. The natural quality of this rhythmic structure may be attributed to the tempo at which it is played.

After looking at the bass score, I realized that it consists of a two-quaver and one-crotchet rhythm. This raises the question of where the accent falls, whether it is on the first or the fifth beat. Based on the position of the break and the melodic leap, it appears that the accent may be on the fifth beat, although I may not be entirely right.

This video from Berklee College of Music presents a straightforward explanation of the rhythm.

item.title: Listening to Heitor Villa-Lobos – 12 Études for Guitar
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Although not typically drawn to classical guitar compositions, I discovered the Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos’ (1887-1957) 12 Études…
item.content:encoded:
Although not typically drawn to classical guitar compositions, I discovered the Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos’ (1887-1957) 12 Études for Guitar and decided to listen to it.

Heitor Villa-Lobos is widely regarded as one of the foremost composers of Latin American music in the 20th century. His work is notable for its unique synthesis of Western classical music and traditional Brazilian folk songs and rhythms. Among his many notable works are the Etudes, composed in 1928 and dedicated to the renowned guitarist Andres Segovia. Alongside their didactic function, these pieces are often featured in live performances due to their musical richness and technical demands.

A few of the études caught my attention.

Study No. 1, employs the technique of right-hand arpeggio. The formula is fixed, interrupted only in measures 23-24. The Study can be divided into three sections: the first section goes until measure 11, which is characterized by stability in the harmony. The second section runs from measure 12 to measure 22, where the arpeggios move down the scale by step, with a pedal E bass note. The third section covers measures 23 to 33, where the range of the notes is expanded. The study was symmetrically constructed with sections of 11 measures. The beauty of this piece lies in the cyclical repetition of each bar, which effectively generates a sense of tension and release.

Study No. 4 is centred on the continuous repetition of chords in the right hand while extensively exploring the harmonic capabilities of the guitar. I hear in these chords elements that anticipate the emergence of Brazilian popular music and bossa nova in the years following its composition.

Study No. 10 is characterized by a range of idiomatic resources and technical challenges, including the use of open strings as pedal notes and ornamental techniques for accompanying open strings. The first 20 bars of the piece are constructed around a fixed position of the left hand, which ascends chromatically, creating a sense of mounting tension. I believe this section showcases Villa-Lobos’ skilful use of harmonic and melodic devices to create a dynamic and engaging piece of music.

item.title: Listening to Beatles – Here, There and Everywhere
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: The Beatles’ “Here, There and Everywhere” is a lyrical and melodic love song, and according to Paul McCartney…
item.content:encoded:
The Beatles’ “Here, There and Everywhere” is a lyrical and melodic love song, and according to Paul McCartney in the McCartney 1, 2, 3 documentary, it is his favourite melody he composed. Despite its compelling melody, it is strange, for me, that it’s not as well-known as other Beatles love songs such as “Something” or “And I Love Her.” Nevertheless, the explicit lyrics leave no room for doubt that the singer wants the lover to be present at all times and everywhere, which makes the theme of the song relatable and impactful.

The structure of the song is intriguing because there is ambiguity about which parts serve as the verse or chorus. There is no melodic and harmonic division that lets the listener distinguish which one serves as chorus or verse. Instead, it is easier to structure the song as Introduction – A – B – A – B – A.

Looking closer at the harmony, it is remarkable that the song has two modulations, which is uncommon in pop music, especially considering the song’s brief 2:24 minute runtime. The song is in the key of G major, and the first modulation happens in the A section, where the music shifts to the relative minor, E, with an F#m7 chord followed by a B major chord, and then moves to E minor chord shifting back to the key of G major.

The other modulation occurs in the B section, where the song modulates to Bb major. This is a relatively dramatic shift, but it is attenuated with preparation at the end of the A section, where the melody sings a Bb note before moving to the B section.

The melody is what I like the most about this music, especially the leap that first appears at bar 5. Upon closer inspection, this leap is similar to SZA’s “Kill Bill” melody (I wrote about it here), which employs an upward preparation followed by a descent with a longer duration. This is a good melodic technique that contributes to the song’s appeal.

The vocal harmonies in the song are simple and effective. According to the producer George Martin, “the boys” hummed basic triads behind the melody, resulting in moving block harmonies.

The song’s arrangement never seems to settle, similar to the Beach Boys’ “God Only Knows,” which was, in fact, an inspiration for McCartney when he wrote, “Here, There and Everywhere.”

In conclusion, “Here, There and Everywhere”, for me, is a great example of a love song that demonstrates mastery of melody and harmony, but also simplicity. It is an excellent example of pop music that uses modulation effectively.

item.title: Research Point 5.4
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Steve Reich (born October 3, 1936, New York, U.S.) is one of the greatest living composers. He is considered…
item.content:encoded:
Steve Reich (born October 3, 1936, New York, U.S.) is one of the greatest living composers. He is considered one of the greatest contributors to the minimalist music movement with a style based on repetitive and rhythmic patterns. His compositions often feature a limited number of instruments.

In 1988, Steve Reich created “Different Trains,” a three-part composition featuring a string quartet and excerpts from audio recordings. This highly personal work draws inspiration from Reich’s recollections of his Jewish upbringing in the United States and his train voyages across the country. The piece’s themes are further contextualized by the vastly different connotations associated with train travel during World War II in Europe, where the transportation of Jews took on an entirely different significance.

The pioneering aspect of the composition lies in its integration of prerecorded sounds with a live string quartet. Sourced from a range of records featuring diverse train sounds and spoken-word samples, including those from Holocaust survivors, this unique blend of live performance and recorded sounds lend a layer of profundity and authenticity to the piece. In particular, the first movement stands out for its complete fusion of the strings and recordings, with the latter serving as the motivic ideas that the strings then elaborate upon. This creative approach, innovative for its time, elevates “Different Trains” to a remarkable work of art.

Across all three movements, a continuous repetition of sounds and patterns interlock and build upon one another, creating a rich and almost hypnotic soundscape. While this reinforces the rhythmic motion of a train, it also enables the listener to become fully immersed in the 30-minute journey of an industrialized landscape, transitioning into haunting melodies and ultimately concluding on a hopeful note.

While I was unable to discern any conventional chord progressions commonly found in classical string quartets, I observed a pronounced typical rhythmic texture primarily conveyed through the strings. In my opinion, this rhythmic quality injects the composition with a sense of emotion, motion, and intrigue, preventing it from succumbing to monotony and repetitiveness.

In my view, the most fascinating aspect of “Different Trains” lies in its harmonious melding of realism and emotion. The inclusion of train whistles and station sounds fosters a vivid and evocative soundscape, while the voices infused throughout the piece infuse a human element that heightens the profound emotional depth already conveyed through the strings.

References

The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica (1998b) Steve Reich | Biography, Music, Tehillim, Music for 18 Musicians, Clapping Music, Different Trains, & Facts. Available at: https://www.britannica.com/biography/Steve-Reich.

Schnipper, M. (2017) Listening to Steve Reich’s Holocaust Opus “Different Trains.” Available at: https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/schnips-picks-listening-to-steve-reichs-holocaust-opus-different-trains/.

Wikipedia contributors (2023a) Different Trains. Available at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Different_Trains.

item.title: Listening to Mozart – String Quartet No. 19 “Dissonance”
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: This String Quartet got my attention right at the beginning. The opening is a slow and haunting Adagio…
item.content:encoded:
This String Quartet got my attention right at the beginning. The opening is a slow and haunting Adagio introduction, which features discordant harmonies that create a sense of tension and unease. The pulsating cello descends chromatically leaving a harmonic ambiguity that surprised me. I wasn’t expecting this kind of introduction by Mozart. The other strings keep playing colliding notes, while the dynamics keep going from p to f and back to p. These 22 bars of the Adagio create a stark contrast with the subsequent Allegro movement, which is characterized by its lively and playful nature.

This string quartet in C major was composed in 1785 and is part of the set of six quartets composed between 1782 and 1785 that he dedicated to Joseph Haydn. This introduction was so innovative and disruptive for its time that it received mixed reviews from critics, publishers and players.

item.title: Research Point 5.1: Bartók’s String Quartet No. 4 (1928)
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Béla Bartók (1881 – 1945) was a Hungarian composer, and one of the most influential figures in 20th-century…
item.content:encoded:
Béla Bartók (1881 – 1945) was a Hungarian composer, and one of the most influential figures in 20th-century music. His pieces are known for their extensive chromaticism and novel rhythms. He is known for collecting and studying authentic Hungarian folk music and incorporating them into his music. He wrote six string quartets which were among his most impressive achievements, being the fourth, the most celebrated.

The String Quartet No.4 has five movements that are written symmetrically. It contains two sets of identical movements with a middle movement which is the central point of the quartet. Here is Bartók explaining it:

“The work is in five movements; their character corresponds to Classical sonata form. The slow movement is the kernel of the work; the other movements are, as it were, arranged in layers around it. Movement IV is a free variation of II, and I and V have the same thematic material; that is, around the kernel (Movement III), metaphorically speaking, I and V are the outer, II and IV the inner layers.” (Keller, 2011).

Although Bartók suggests that the nature of the first and final movements corresponds with that of the Classical sonata form, I believe that he merely employed the concept of the sonata form and utilized it liberally as a framework for his composition, without adhering rigorously to its conventions. Distinct motifs are present in the quartet, rather than explicitly articulated themes as found in the sonatas of Beethoven or Haydn. These motific ideas tend to appear for a very short time and disappear quickly. This reminds me of Debussy.

Upon listening to this piece for the first time, I found it much harder to distinguish the sonata sections, in contrast to Haydn’s quartet, wherein such segments were easily discernible. However, after reading the score and watching Andreyev’s analysis, I was able to understand the structure of the piece, the division of the sections, and the appearance of each motif.

When listening to the entire movement, I found it to be incredibly radical and challenging to follow. This left me confused, especially knowing that Bartók employs several counterpoint techniques that are commonly used in the works of many Western composers, including contrary motion, imitation, inversions, and call-and-response.

Bartók demonstrates an innovative use of the quartet by investigating the sonorities of the three instruments through techniques such as extreme note ranges, varied glissandos, and his unique interpretation of pizzicato, which involves a vigorous plucking motion that produces a sharp snap upon the string’s impact with the instrument.

References

Stevens, H. (2023) Béla Bartók | Hungarian composer. Available at: https://www.britannica.com/biography/Bela-Bartok (Accessed: March 28, 2023).

Keller, J.M. (2011) Chamber Music: A Listener’s Guide. Oxford University Press, USA.

Samuel Andreyev (2017) Béla Bartók’s String Quartet N° 4: Analysis. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pMV7KaxyBIE.

item.title: Listening to Devonté Hynes – The Long Ride II
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.category: Part 4 Moving into the Twentieth Century
item.description: I decided to listen to Devonté Hynes’ music after reading a review in the Guardian of his concert…
item.content:encoded:
I decided to listen to Devonté Hynes’ music after reading a review in the Guardian of his concert with the London Symphony Orchestra. I didn’t know his work, so it was interesting to dig a bit into his work.

Devonté Hynes’ Long Ride II is a two-piano rendition that was written for HBO’s Series “We Are Who We Are.” Hynes is primarily known for his R&B and indie music, but he has recently been exploring classical music, which I find an interesting move.

The Long Ride II features a repetitive arpeggio and chords in one of the pianos, while the other builds upon the background, almost as if it is improvising. It has an impressionist feeling of improvisation, and perhaps in the live version, the pianist is really improvising.

The piece is based on an F major chord, and there doesn’t seem to be a defined structure. Instead, there is an increase in texture that keeps growing until almost the finale where one of the pianos plays alone, which is like a return to the beginning.

Although Devonté Hynes’ Long Ride II is an intriguing piece of music that highlights his exploration of classical music, I personally don’t find its repetitive nature appealing. However, I believe that delving deeper into the music can reveal the specific elements of change or lack thereof that either draw us in or push us away. While there are examples of repetitive music that do appeal to me (such as compositions by Steve Reich, for instance), it seems that in the case of Long Ride II, there may be either insufficient or excessive variation that prevents it from capturing my interest. Nonetheless, I still believe it was worth giving it a listen.

item.title: Listening to Gamelan
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.category: Part 4 Moving into the Twentieth Century
item.description: After reading about Debussy’s fascination with Javanese gamelan music and its influence on his compositions, I became intrigued…
item.content:encoded:
After reading about Debussy’s fascination with Javanese gamelan music and its influence on his compositions, I became intrigued and decided to listen to it myself.

Gamelan music, originating from Java in Indonesia, features an ensemble of tuned metal instruments, including gongs and percussion instruments. This type of music is also found throughout Southeast Asia. The sound of gamelan music is characterized by an interplay of metallic sounds defined by one of two scales: slendro, which divides the octave into five equal intervals, and pelog, which divides it into seven.

Balinese music is structured like a tree, with different instruments symbolizing the trunk, branches, and flowers. The core melody, or pokok, is played by one group of instruments in one octave. Another group stresses this melody at regular intervals, while a third expands it into a full melody with a range of two to three octaves. A fourth group doubles and paraphrases it an octave higher, while a fifth group plays an ornamental figuration. Gongs punctuate and structure the music, while the drums provide rhythmic support.

Upon listening to gamelan music, one is struck by the clear and metallic sounds, which evoke the stirring of a thousand bells. The interplay of the sounds is delicate and complex and possesses a sensuous charm. The overall effect is one of mystery, which can be quite overpowering.

References

Channing, A. (2020) Balinese gamelan: a complete guide to a unique world of sound. Available at: https://www.songlines.co.uk/features/balinese-gamelan-a-complete-guide-to-a-unique-world-of-sound (Accessed: February 28, 2023).

item.title: Listening to Haydn – String Quartet in E-flat, Op. 33, No. 2
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.category: Part 4 Moving into the Twentieth Century
item.description: In 1781, Franz Joseph Haydn composed his Op. 33 String Quartets, which he dedicated to the Grand Duke…
item.content:encoded:
In 1781, Franz Joseph Haydn composed his Op. 33 String Quartets, which he dedicated to the Grand Duke Paul of Russia. Consequently, these quartets are frequently referred to as the “Russian” quartets. The second quartet in E-flat, commonly known as the “Joke” quartet, is the most celebrated of the set. The nickname “Joke” is believed to have originated from the final movement, which incorporates a series of playful musical jokes, such as a mock conclusion and an unexpected outburst of powerful chords, which leave the listener with a feeling of joyful surprise.

Comprising four movements, the piece follows a a non-traditional structure. The first movement is composed in Sonata form, while the second, instead of being a Minuet and Trio, is a Scherzo and Trio. The third and fourth movements are both arranged as a Rondo.

The quartet opens with a delightful theme that is subsequently fragmented, manipulated, and reassembled in various ways. Personally, I found this movement to be lighthearted and fascinating, particularly as Haydn deftly plays with the theme, departing from and returning to it, as demonstrated in the following example.

The second movement caught my attention with the violin slides present in the Trio section. The movement has a dance-like quality to it, with the second violin intermittently interacting with the first violin. At the same time, the viola and cello provide a steady foundation for the piece.

The third movement presents a stark contrast, opening with the lower strings and at a slower tempo in a Largo style. I found the movement to be somewhat dramatic, particularly with the powerful forte chords played by all strings. An illustration of this effect is evident in the following example towards the end of the movement.

The Rondo in the fourth movement shows a catchy, memorable theme that is both danceable and owns a humorous character. The coda segment of the movement is surprising, as the expected recurrence of the theme is subject to hesitant pauses, creating a sense of suspense and uncertainty for the listener. The final pause builds a sense of anticipation, ultimately ending with a soft whisper that leaves the listener with an unresolved sense of closure.

item.title: Listening to Igor Stravinsky – Symphonies of Wind Instruments
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.category: Part 4 Moving into the Twentieth Century
item.description: During my research on Debussy, I discovered that he and Stravinsky were close friends. Following Debussy’s death, Stravinsky…
item.content:encoded:
During my research on Debussy, I discovered that he and Stravinsky were close friends. Following Debussy’s death, Stravinsky paid tribute by composing a serene chorale, which was later incorporated into the “Symphonies of Wind Instruments” in 1920. In 1945, Stravinsky revised the work, publishing it in 1947, and made alterations including the removal of the alto flute and alto clarinet, as well as reworking the musical score.

After listening to it the first time, I absolutely loved this piece. I keep finding Stravinsky’s work amazing and it’s one of the composers I most like to listen to, but at the same time is the one I find most difficult to analyze. In the next paragraphs I’ll try to understand what made me like this piece.

The first hint comes from the title. The “Symphonies of Wind Instruments” is a musical work with a title that alludes to the original definition of symphony (as opposed to the musical form) as a harmonious blending of instruments. That’s one of the characteristics of this piece that stroke me right away. The interplay between the different wind instruments, particularly in terms of the contrasting chromatic tones between the woodwinds and brass, is particularly striking. Stravinsky’s manipulation of the instruments, such as in bar 3 where he plays a Bb in the trumpet and a B in the clarinets, creates a unique sonic landscape that highlights the tonal differences between the instruments.

The formal structure of the piece proves to be elusive and challenging to categorize. It frequently alternates between tempos, including 144, 108, and 72 beats per minute, which are related by a ratio of 2:3:4. The fluctuating time signature only adds to the impression of multiple distinct musical ideas being woven together in the composition.

From the beginning, Stravinsky introduces contrasting thematic materials, switching between joyful flutes, mournful full chords, and the chorale theme, which symbolizes Debussy’s death or funeral. Throughout the piece, there is no clear narrative or progression. The musical ideas seem to shift abruptly, giving the impression of a series of disconnected fragments.

The chorale theme, which recurs throughout the piece, serves as a unifying thread and provides the piece with a sense of direction. It becomes the focus of the conclusion, which is joyful and uplifting, spreading a sense of peace and resolution.

item.title: Listening to Bach: Brandenburg Concerto No. 5 in D Major
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Reading “How to Listen to Great Music” by Robert Greenberg has been an invaluable resource in learning how…
item.content:encoded:
Reading “How to Listen to Great Music” by Robert Greenberg has been an invaluable resource in learning how to listen to and analyze music. The author suggests listening to Bach’s Brandenburg Concerto No. 5 as a way to gain a deeper understanding of Baroque concertos, with a particular emphasis on the ritornello. The concerto, which is composed for flute, solo violin, harpsichord, and strings, presents several interesting features upon listening and studying the score.

Right from the start of the concerto, I noticed the ritornello theme, which was highlighted by Greenberg, and how it reappears in fragments throughout the movement before being repeated in the end after the harpsichord solo.

As Greenberg explains in his book, the function of the ritornello theme is to create a sense of logical inevitability, providing a feeling of returning home and familiarity, even if only for a brief moment. This helps the listener relax and not be overwhelmed by constant new sounds.

It works similarly to a chorus in modern-day popular music. but it typically appears at the beginning and end of the movement, while choruses in contemporary music typically appear in the middle and end of songs. I am curious as to why composers have shifted the placement of this familiar theme from the beginning to the middle of their compositions.

This movement also stands out for its unique use of the harpsichord as a solo instrument. While it was often used as a continuo instrument in the past, Bach elevated its role to that of a true solo instrument, giving it equal importance alongside the flute and violin. According to Greenberg, this concerto marks a significant moment in music history as the harpsichord’s solo capabilities were truly showcased for the first time.

The second movement of the concerto is an affettuoso, characterized by its melodic singing between the flute and violin. As I listened, I noticed two features that I had previously encountered in Bach’s violin sonata – the use of long, melodic lines that persistently avoid resolving to a steady cadence (as exemplified by the flute’s quick movement to C), and the repetition of a rhythmic pattern (in this case, quaver-quaver-dotted semiquaver-demisemiquaver) throughout the entire movement.

The third movement starts with the exposition of a fugal theme by the violin, which is then repeated by the flute. However, as the movement progresses, the violin and flute often play in unison, rather than in counterpoint as is typical in a true fugue. Despite this, there is a significant use of polyphonic texture throughout the movement.

item.title: Listening to Bach: Sonata No. 4 for violin and harpsichord in C Minor, BMV 1017: 1. Siciliano
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: This sonata looks like a good example of Baroque music, characterized by its long melodic lines and ornamental…
item.content:encoded:
This sonata looks like a good example of Baroque music, characterized by its long melodic lines and ornamental elements. Upon listening to it for the first time played by Glenn Gould and Yehudi Menuhin, I feel that there’s an interesting contrast between the smoothness of the violin and the pointed, moving accompaniment of the harpsichord. After listening to it several times and studying the score, I noticed several unique features.

One of the key observations I made was that the harpsichord had a repetitive pattern, which allowed the violin to take centre stage. The bass harpsichord usually played a continuous arpeggio starting on the downbeat, while the treble harpsichord had an upward and downward motion with its highest note on the second note of the violin rhythm. The violin melody, in section A, seemed to be a long single melody that lasted 16 bars. Although I could definitely hear that the melody line didn’t settle until bar 16 and it seemed like Bach avoided a cadence in bars 8 and 12, I was unsure of how he achieved this effect. But my tutor helped clarify that it was a mixture of harmony, not having a perfect cadence, melody/rhythm notes that cross bars, and the use of weaker inversions of chords that gave a feeling of movement instead of a final rest. I hadn’t thought about how inverting chords could transmit a sense movement and it made much more sense to me after his answer.

Another observation I made was the rhythm of the violin melody and its repetition. This movement of the sonata is a Siciliano which is a musical style from the baroque era, usually in a slow 6/8 time and in a minor key. The violin follows the traditional Siciliana rhythms with a dotted quaver – semiquaver – quaver. It’s interesting to notice that Bach uses this exact rhythm 36 times and some of its variations throughout this movement but without making it feel repetitive. The use of ornamentation is essential here.

Another observation I made was the rhythm of the violin melody and its repetition. This movement of the sonata is a Siciliano, a musical style from the Baroque era, usually in a slow 6/8 time and in a minor key. The violin follows the traditional Siciliana rhythms with a dotted quaver-semiquaver-quaver. It’s interesting to notice that Bach uses this exact rhythm 36 times and some of its variations throughout this movement without making it feel repetitive. The use of ornamentation is essential here.

Overall, I find this piece to be deceptively simple yet incredibly evocative and emotionally charged. Reflecting on its various features has helped me gain a deeper understanding of how to approach my assignment with greater insight and understanding.

item.title: Listening to SZA – Kill Bill
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Although I appreciate pop music, I’m usually turned away from songs that are too popular on the charts.…
item.content:encoded:
Although I appreciate pop music, I’m usually turned away from songs that are too popular on the charts. But, when I stumbled upon SZA’s “Kill Bill” on the radio without knowing what it was, I was extremely surprised. The song really caught my attention. My impression was that the song never settled down, a feeling (a very good feeling) I also had when listening to God Only Knows.

The aspect that impressed me the most was the chorus vocal melody. It was straightforward yet stunning and flowed smoothly. Upon transcribing it, I discovered the song was in Ab Major, but the vocal melody only utilized the Ab once on the last note of the 4th beat, which was a rather weak one. There was also an A flat, a chromatic note just a half-step from the tonic, leading to a sense of uncertainty and incompletion.

The chord progression also caught my attention. Throughout the song, it used the same progression: Bbm-Eb-Ab-F or ii-V-I-VI. This again contributed to a sense of instability as it started on ii and placed the I on the third bar, which is a weaker position for establishing the key. The final chord was a modulation to a chromatic chord of F Major, which was my favourite part of the chorus. It was playful, and daring, and complemented the lyrics perfectly (e.g. “Rather be in jail than alone”).

But right from the beginning, the song starts off sounding vague. There’s a distinct out-of-tune waver that is completely undefined. From that point, the song could head in any direction. Then, the drum beat enters and as with any typical pop song, you anticipate listening to a four-beat loop until the vocals begin. But the vocals come in on the fourth beat, like an anacrusis, unexpectedly.

Ultimately, I don’t think “Kill Bill” will be regarded as a masterpiece like “God Only Knows,” but in today’s landscape of overwhelming similar-sounding pop music, I found the song to be invigorating. I hope it serves as inspiration for other artists to create pop music that departs from standard harmonic and melodic structures.

item.title: Listening to Schubert: String Quintet in C Major
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Lately, I’ve been enjoying it more and more the cello. Actually, I think I’m particularly drawn to low-pitched…
item.content:encoded:
Lately, I’ve been enjoying it more and more the cello. Actually, I think I’m particularly drawn to low-pitched instruments like the acoustic bass, bassoon, and cello. When I learned that Schubert wrote a piece for a string quintet with a second cello instead of the usual second viola, I was curious to listen to it.

Listening to it was an emotional journey. The piece seemed to effortlessly shift from one mood to another. For instance, in the first movement (10:03-13:05), it transitioned from a beautiful melodic line to an intense, almost violent cello and back to the melodic line and again back to an angry mood. All this in just 3 minutes.

Sometimes the piece reminded me of Beethoven. For example, at the beginning of the third movement (00:00-04:03), where there is such a strength that it almost looks like an entire orchestra is playing. I think sometimes I could hear a brass instrument within the strings, and it’s amazing how Schubert was able to create such magic.

I think the decision to use two cellos gave the piece a full orchestral sound, especially during moments with a darker mood, such as the first movement.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this piece and it has sparked my interest in exploring Schubert’s other works.

item.title: Listening to Caroline Shaw & Sō Percussion – To the Sky
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I recently became a fan of Caroline Shaw after listening to her Partita for 8 Singer. I have…
item.content:encoded:
I recently became a fan of Caroline Shaw after listening to her Partita for 8 Singer. I have since listened to some of her other songs, including “To the Sky,” which features Shaw’s exceptional vocals and the talented musicianship of the exploratory New York ensemble Sō Percussion. The lyrics for the song are taken from Anne Steele’s 18th-century hymnal, the Sacred Harp.

The song starts off with a gentle hum and softly rumbling marimba, gradually increasing in intensity and culminating in Shaw’s powerful vocals. Shaw’s music often showcases a dynamic range and the versatility of the voice as an instrument.

In addition to Shaw’s vocals, Sō Percussion’s expert use of percussion instruments creates a rich and complex soundscape that perfectly complements Shaw’s voice.

After a gentle start, the song builds to a climax with exuberance and then fades away, leaving me with a sense of awe and wonder.

Overall, “To the Sky” is a beautiful and moving piece of music that has left me wanting to hear more from Shaw.

item.title: Listening to Georg Friedrich Händel – Dixit Dominus
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Because of Project 3.0, I started listening to Händel’s Dixit Dominus’ first movement and ended up listening to…
item.content:encoded:
Because of Project 3.0, I started listening to Händel’s Dixit Dominus’ first movement and ended up listening to the entire work.

Georg Friedrich Händel was a German-born composer (1685 – 1759) who worked in Germany, and Italy and settled in London. He was heavily influenced by the middle-German polyphonic choral tradition and the Italian Baroque style. Händel’s music is considered a pinnacle of the “high baroque” style and he is widely regarded as one of the greatest composers of his era.

Dixit Dominus is a psalm setting completed in 1707 and is scored for an SSATB choir and soloists, strings and continuo.

Although I enjoyed the entire piece, I found the first movement to be the most interesting and surprising. As a psalm, I was expecting a contemplative and loving sound. Instead, I found it to be rough and even a bit hostile. This was due to the rhythmic vitality which felt a lot like a warlike snare.

It is not surprising that the piece’s opening movement evokes a warlike sound, given the psalm’s theme about God giving the king of Israel the power to defeat his enemies (Clássicos dos Clássicos, 2019).

The ending of Dominus a dextris tuis is another example of the power of the choir, as it resembles a war chant. I imagine this would likely have been striking to an audience in the 1700s, given the religious context in which it was performed.

The choir in this piece reminded me of Caroline Shaw’s Partita for 8 Voices. I believe that they are similar in their exploration of different vocal timbers and ranges, either together or in counterpoint. Additionally, the staccato rhythm of the voices in both pieces creates an almost drum-like feeling.

References

Clássicos dos Clássicos (2019) Händel – Dixit Dominus (Disse o Senhor), HWV 232. Available at: https://classicosdosclassicos.mus.br/obras/handel-dixit-dominus-disse-o-senhor-hwv-232/ (Accessed: December 10, 2022).

item.title: Listening to Franz Liszt – Les Préludes
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Les Préludes is a symphonic poem composed by Franz Liszt and premiered in 1854. His symphonic poem is…
item.content:encoded:
Les Préludes is a symphonic poem composed by Franz Liszt and premiered in 1854. His symphonic poem is one of his most famous compositions and is often seen as a paradigmatic example of the genre. This work is based on a poem by Alphonse de Lamartine of the same name that explores ideas of fate and destiny. Liszt uses a variety of musical devices to illustrate Lamartine’s poem, including changes in tempo and dynamics, harmonic shifts, and orchestral colour.

Liszt’s use of thematic transformation in Les Préludes is one of the most striking aspects of the work. Thematic transformation is a compositional technique whereby a musical theme is altered or transformed in order to create a distinct idea or mood. In Les Préludes, Liszt uses this technique to significant effect, transforming the main theme of destiny into several different musical ideas that represent different aspects of the poem.

Beginning with three notes (C-B-E), the piece is a dreamy introduction. In a thematic transformation, this motif will be repeated throughout the work. Using this single motif, the music moves from a dawn of enchantment to a tumultuous battle to a triumphant ending.

My first experience listening to Liszt’s Les Préludes was incredibly moving. Liszt’s use of thematic transformation made me feel the tension he had created, although sometimes it was challenging to discern where the main theme was. I really like this piece of music.

References

Les Préludes | work by Liszt (2013). Available at: https://www.britannica.com/topic/Les-Preludes (Accessed: 30 November 2022).

item.title: Listening to Luís de Freitas Branco – Suite Alentejana No. 1
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Luís de Freitas Branco was a Portuguese composer, musicologist, and professor of music who played a pre-eminent part…
item.content:encoded:
Luís de Freitas Branco was a Portuguese composer, musicologist, and professor of music who played a pre-eminent part in developing Portuguese music in the first half of the 20th century. He wrote over 150 pieces of music, including orchestral works, chamber music and works for the stage, as well as songs and choral works. Suite Alentejana No. 1 is one of his most famous works and is known for its energetic rhythms, colourful orchestration and vibrant melodies.

The piece is written for a large orchestra with 3 flutes, 2 oboes, Cor Anglais, 2 clarinets, bass clarinet, 2 bassoons, 4 trumpets, 3 trombones, tuba, timpani, bass drum, cymbals, triangle, castanets and harp, as well as strings.

Luís de Freitas Branco’s Suite Alentejana No. 1, written in 1919, is a celebrated work demonstrating his preference for Portugal’s Alentejo region. Personally, the third and final movement, known as the Fandango, stands out for its vibrant energy and eloquent orchestration. It is written for orchestra with elements of folk music from Alentejo such as a binary-metered rhythm and castanets incorporated into the piece. The form of the piece is tripartite (A-B-A), with a Cor Anglais solo leading to a choral section in between two energised sections featuring returning themes. As we close the Fandango brilliantly, the exuberance and vigour of the first section return.

item.title: Listening to Georg Philipp Telemann – Sonata in D Major, TWV 44:1
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Sonata in D Major, TWV 44:1 is a piece of Baroque music composed by the German composer Georg…
item.content:encoded:
Sonata in D Major, TWV 44:1 is a piece of Baroque music composed by the German composer Georg Philipp Telemann (1681-1767). It combines elements of concerto and suite genres and is composed for trumpet, strings, and basso continuo. 

Three movements make up the piece, each with its own distinctive character. In Sinfonia Spirituoso, the opening trumpet fanfare presents a lively and energetic start. The second movement, Largo, displays two violins in intimate harmony with the basso continuo. With its lively tempo and energetic tone, the closing movement Vivace brings the piece to a triumphant conclusion.

I found it to be a captivating work of Baroque music with an interesting and multifaceted composition. The opening fanfare immediately captivated me with its bold and triumphant sound.

item.title: Listening to The Pharcyde – Runnin
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In the last few weeks, I’ve been reading the book Dilla Time, about the life of James DeWitt…
item.content:encoded:
In the last few weeks, I’ve been reading the book Dilla Time, about the life of James DeWitt Yancey, better known as J Dilla and Jay Dee. He was an American record producer, drummer, rapper, songwriter, and rapper. It is Dilla’s “drunk”, and “laid back” time-feel that makes his work unique and difficult to interpret, define, or translate. His production style has inspired some of the world’s most renowned pop, hip-hop, and jazz musicians — achieved, in part, because he didn’t quantize his music (Fitzpatrick, 2011).

While I don’t listen to a lot of hip-hop, I was intrigued by his stories and how he blew everyone away with his eccentric rhythms, so I decided to check out some of the music he produced or composed (Stadnicki, 2017). My favourite was Running by The Pharcyde, released in 1995.

It begins with a simple maracas sample from James Moody, followed by acoustic guitar from Luiz Bonfá. As I listen to these samples, I realize that the tempo is not always right. I start to understand why people talk about J Dilla when the drums start playing. It seems like the kick drum is rushing (perhaps running?) while the snare is dragging after the hi-hats. This results in strangely relaxed music, with an endless forward motion.

These kinds of not quantized drum sounds are somehow normal nowadays and explored by a lot of musicians, but I can imagine how refreshing it was to listen to such a relaxed and “humanized” beat after listening to so much on-tempo electronic music from the late ’80s and early ’90s.

References

Fitzpatrick, R. (2011) J Dilla: The mozart of hip-hop, The Guardian. Guardian News and Media. Available at: https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/jan/27/j-dilla-suite-ma-dukes (Accessed: November 3, 2022).

Stadnicki, D.A. (2017) “Play like jay: Pedagogies of drum kit performance after J Dilla,” Journal of Popular Music Education, 1(3), pp. 253–280. Available at: https://doi.org/10.1386/jpme.1.3.253_1.

item.title: Listening to Aaron Copland – Letter from Home
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: “Letter from Home” is a composition by American composer Aaron Copland, written in 1944 and commissioned as a…
item.content:encoded:
“Letter from Home” is a composition by American composer Aaron Copland, written in 1944 and commissioned as a patriotic work by Paul Whiteman for his Radio Hall of Fame Orchestra. The piece is a reflection on the experiences of soldiers returning home from war, and the changes that they have undergone during their time away. The piece is written in the style of a letter from a soldier to his family and conveys the bittersweet emotions of coming home after having seen the horrors of war.

The piece begins with a sombre, reflective melody, as the soldier reflects on his experiences and considers the changes that have taken place in his life since departing. The music slowly builds to a more upbeat, hopeful tone, as the soldier finds comfort in the thought of being reunited with his family and friends. The piece ends with a triumphant, joyous melody, as the soldier celebrates the joy of being home. The instrumentation is sparse and haunting, evoking a sense of loneliness and longing.

Ultimately, “Letter from Home” is a powerful and poignant tribute to the soldiers who have sacrificed so much for their country. Through its emotional intensity and evocative musical language, Copland captures the complex emotions of a soldier returning home.

item.title: Listening to Keith Jarrett – My Song
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Keith Jarrett is a celebrated American jazz musician and composer. He has been active since the 1960s and…
item.content:encoded:
Keith Jarrett is a celebrated American jazz musician and composer. He has been active since the 1960s and has released several acclaimed albums, such as My Song, which came out in 1978. His music often features a sublime simplicity and directness that has made it a favorite among jazz enthusiasts.

The title track of Keith Jarrett’s 1978 album, My Song, is a timeless piece featuring the collaborative efforts of the European Quartet. The melody is introduced by a pensive piano movement that is soon joined by Jan Garabek’s saxophone and Jon Christensen’s percussion, which uses shakers and cymbals to create a soft and muted backdrop. Over the years, My Song has become a popular standard among jazz musicians, with Pat Metheny being one of its most notable interpreters.

item.title: Listening to Jörg Widmann – Viola Concerto
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: It was while researching Berlioz’s Harold in Italy that I came across an article by French violist Antoine…
item.content:encoded:
It was while researching Berlioz’s Harold in Italy that I came across an article by French violist Antoine Tamestit. This article stated, in 2015, when he played Harold with John Eliot for the first time, he told German composer Jörg Widmann how delighted he was with the piece. Therefore, Widmann composed a viola concerto filled with narration, journeys and interactions with multiple orchestral instruments.

Based on this description, I decided to watch Tamestit’s performance with the Frankfurt Radio Symphony conducted by Andrés Orozco-Estrada.

My overall reaction was one of awe and I still don’t know if I liked it or not. However, I believe that was the purpose of this concerto. In one interview, Tamestit explains that this piece is intended to disorient the listener (Todes, 2021). While I sometimes understood what the composer was saying, other times I felt disoriented and I wondered if it wasn’t just too much theatrical for show’s sake.

In the same interview, Tamestit talks about how the instrumentation is unusual. This concerto, for instance, requires the soloist to scream throughout and requires the pianist to hold a whiskey glass.

I wasn’t expecting such a theatrical performance with such an emphasis on the viola soloist. But as an homage or follow-up to Berlioz’s symphony, Widmann seemed to want to keep the viola at the center of this performance.

The viola is the focus of this piece, for me. As it takes the listener through the viola’s different sounds, blending and clashing with other instruments, and finding its place within the orchestra.

Berlioz’s symphony and this concerto have many connections, but for me, the biggest one is the instrument’s representation. In Harold in Italy, the viola embodied Harold, here the instrument symbolized itself. As I realized, Widmann attempted to meta-characterize the viola. And that was a brilliant idea.

References

Todes, A. (2021) ‘it is in my blood’: Antoine Tamestit on Jörg Widmann’s Viola Concerto, London Symphony Orchestra. Available at: https://lso.co.uk/whats-on/alwaysplaying/read/1473-it-is-in-my-blood-antoine-tamestit-on-jorg-widmann-s-viola-concerto.html (Accessed: October 19, 2022).

item.title: Listening to Omar Thomas – Come Sunday II. Shout!
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: On the Academic Music Discord server, someone posted a video about Omar Thomas, a composer I had never…
item.content:encoded:
On the Academic Music Discord server, someone posted a video about Omar Thomas, a composer I had never heard of before.

A composer, arranger and educator, Omar Thomas was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., in 1984. His parents are Guyanese, and he moved to Boston in 2006 to pursue a Master of Music degree at New England Conservatory.

A piece written for a wind ensemble, Piano and Drum Set, Come Sunday celebrates the Hammond organ’s central role in black worship. The second movement, Shout!, is an energetic celebration of gospel, jazz and blues, which shows influences from Duke Wellington and Charles Mingus as well as traditional church singing.

In listening to Shout!, I was surprised at how energetic it was after the slow and melodic first movement. There was an instant connection for me to the rhythm of this piece, marked by brass, bass, and drums, with the repetitive woodwinds in a high register adding the necessary tension.

As I listened to this piece, I was reminded of 70s funk horns and woodwinds. That’s what makes this piece so beautiful. Mixing genres and decades, creating a fresh and joyful time for the listener and for the players.

Since I am unfamiliar with much of the new classical music, I am enjoying this opportunity to listen to contemporary composers. At the same time that I study traditional techniques, I believe this will facilitate me in understanding the paths new composers are taking.

item.title: Listening to Tan Dun, Eldbjørg Hemsing – Violin Concerto “Rhapsody & Fantasia”: Ia. Rock the Violin in Rhapsody. Hip-Hop
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In another Spotify discovery, I listened to a piece that I had never heard before. My attention was…
item.content:encoded:
In another Spotify discovery, I listened to a piece that I had never heard before. My attention was immediately captured when a traditional drum kit entered playing a classic hip-hop pattern in the first 16 seconds.

Rock the Violin in Rhapsody. Hip-Hop is the first movement of the Violin Concerto “Rhapsody & Fantasy” by Eldbjørg Hemsing and Tan Dun. Hemsing is one of the best violinists in Norway, while Tan Dun is one of the most renowned conductors and composers that lives in New York but was born in China.

Having found a score for this concerto, I discovered that it includes a strong percussion section with five players, in addition to woodwinds, brass, and strings. It’s easy to hear the rhythm throughout this piece since it’s very heavy on it.

My favourite aspect of the piece was the constant play between rhythmic, hip-hop ambient and the almost wild solo violin. The play kept the piece alive and prevented it from becoming monotonous, which could happen with a simple hip-hop beat.

As described by Xenia Hanusiak in her article, the composer calls this Rhapsody and Fantasia “the perfect result” of his thirty-five years of living in New York. It is one of the most interesting pieces I have heard in a while due to its combination of street sound rhythm, classical Chinese instruments, and a harsh nordic violin.

item.title: Listening to Max Bruch – Concerto for Clarinet & Viola, Op. 88: I. Andante Con Moto
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Max Bruch (1838-1920) is a well-known prolific German composer. During his long career, he taught, conducted, and composed.…
item.content:encoded:
Max Bruch (1838-1920) is a well-known prolific German composer. During his long career, he taught, conducted, and composed. In 1911, Bruch composed the Double Concerto in E minor, Op.88. This piece was composed for his son Max Felix Bruch, who was a first-class clarinettist.

A review of Bruch’s Double Concerto Op.88 premiere, published in Allgemeine Musikzeitung Zeitung No. 40 (1913), called it “harmless,” “weak,” and “uninteresting” (Fifield, 1988).

Initially, I was intrigued by the strange combination of clarinet and viola in this Double Concerto. My impression after listening to this piece is that both instruments can very well mimic human timbres. As a result, the solo instruments have a lyrical and melodic sound. As the two solo instruments weave melodies around each other, the orchestra provides a stable backdrop.

The first movement of this work presents Bruch’s two solo instruments in a rather dramatic manner. In the beginning, the solo viola is boldly introduced, followed by the clarinet. Throughout the entire movement, it feels as if both instruments are having an intimate conversation.

Upon hearing this movement, I felt as if there was nothing shocking and nothing wrong, at least to my ears. In addition to being a conservative, Bruch was opposed to ‘modern madness’ and ‘modernists’ like Strauss, Reger, and Debussy (the latter he termed an ‘unqualified scribbler’). As a whole, I enjoyed this piece, especially the interplay between the two solo instruments.

References

Fifield, C. (1988) Max Bruch his life and works. London: Gollancz.

Viola and clarinet concerto and other viola compositions by Bruch (no date) Viola in Music.com. Available at: http://www.viola-in-music.com/viola-and-clarinet-concerto.html .

item.title: Listening to Masses
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: During my research, I listened to masses from different periods of history, but my focus was exclusively on…
item.content:encoded:
During my research, I listened to masses from different periods of history, but my focus was exclusively on the Kyrie.

Machaut: Messe de Nostra Dame: Kyrie (1365)
(Guillaume & Royllart, 2016)

This Ordinary of the Mass composed before 1365 is considered the earliest complete setting attributable to any single composer. The Kyrie is written in polyphony for four voices and features lots of melismas. This piece is divided into three sections, each with the same structure: polyphony – plainchant – polyphony. As far as the sound quality is concerned, I found it to be very diverse, with each voice having its own distinct characteristics, but working together to create a pleasing whole.

Victoria: Missa O magnum mysterium: Kyrie (1592)
(Smith & de, 1997)

O magnum mysterium (published in 1572) became the basis for Victoria’s 1592 Mass for a four-part choir. Since this short Kyrie is in imitation polyphonic texture, the voices do not appear to have any real distinctive characteristic, but rather blend together to achieve a more common sound.

Bach: Mass in B minor: Kyrie I (1749)
(Herreweghe, 2011)

Compared to my previous two masses, this is a big difference. This work is for five voices with instrumental accompaniment, which makes a completely different sound from choral masses without accompaniment. It is evident that Bach is stepping up the masses from church music to concert music, making them suitable for a concert hall. In this polyphonic Kyrie, what I found most interesting is the way, from bar 30, the sound never settles until the last bar. The tension and expectation lasts for about 5 minutes.

Mozart: Great Mass in C minor K.427: Kyrie (1783)
(Bernstein et al., 1991)

After listening to it, I understand why it is considered one of Mozart’s greatest works. It is a magnificent composition for two soprano soloists, a tenor and a bass, a double chorus and a large orchestra. Similarly to Bach’s mass, Mozart wanted to make the experience more performance and entertainment-based, instead of contemplative and solemn. For me, the most appealing part of this Kyrie is the soprano solo, particularly when it reaches a low Ab and jumps two octaves higher in the following measure.

Beethoven: Mass in C Major, Op.86:I. Kyrie (1807)
(Kampen, K.V. et al., 2005)

Compared to the previous masses I had listened to, the texture of this Kyrie surprised me. In my opinion, Beethoven decided to compose a homophonic-based mass that heavily relied on the choir. Throughout, there is an intriguing play of dynamics, swaying up and down and conveying different emotions in a short space of time, with some parts with breathtaking soaring voices. A note about Gloria in excelsis Deo, which is one of my favourite versions I’ve heard.

Bruckner: Mass in E minor: Kyrie (1866)
(Parkman, 2019)

It’s a mass that feels like a travel back in time, stripped of all instrumental accompaniment and focusing primarily on choral. The combination of choir and brass in this Kyrie really caught my attention. This created a very dramatic and mournful sound. But I was most impressed by the use of silences and the absence of sound in some parts, which gave this piece a huge hollowness.

References

Guillaume and Royllart, P. (2016) Machaut, G. de: Messe de nostre dame (diabolus in Musica, guerber), Youtube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lOVsY1rxJB8.

Smith, S. and de, V.T.L. (1997) Victoria, T.L. de: Vocal music (tenebrae responsories) (ensemble Corund, S. Smith), Youtube. Naxos Digital Services US Inc. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGyWrtWgHjA.

Herreweghe, P. (2011) Mass in B minor BWV 232 ; Collegium Vocale Gent ; Philippe Herreweghe, Youtube. Harmonia mundi. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zS2biN257sQ.

Bernstein, L. et al. (1991) Große Messe C-Moll K 427 (417a): Version: Franz Beyer = great mass in C minor = Grande Messe en ut mineur, Youtube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GUtLXacCT5M.

Kampen, K.V. et al. (2005) Messe C-Dur = Mass in C major = Messe en UT majeur: Op. 86, Spotify. Hänssler Classic. Available at: https://open.spotify.com/track/2k7AQGyLChW5JlcWhvBwLc?si=39803a01a70f4435.

item.title: Listening to José Almarcha – Casa del Gallego
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: As usual, my Spotify is on shuffle and today I heard some flamenco, which I am not particularly…
item.content:encoded:
As usual, my Spotify is on shuffle and today I heard some flamenco, which I am not particularly familiar with, but enjoy listening to occasionally. This song caught my attention, so I listened carefully.

Originally from Ciudad Real, José Almarcha is an outstanding guitarist and composer. As a student of flamenco at the Córdoba Conservatory of Music, José studied with flamenco masters including Paco Serrano and Niño de Pura. A number of dancers have been accompanied by him, including Olga Pericet, Marco Flores, and Antonio Canales. His albums have received excellent reviews and he has been hailed as one of Spain’s most promising flamenco guitarists.

The singer recently released Casa del Gallego, which is a farruca, a dance-centric style of flamenco characterized by sombre virtuosity, aggressive footwork, and dramatic tempo changes. 

In this song, the melody is introduced by a flamenco guitar riff, but a few seconds into the song, there’s a surprise: a trombone with a delay effect. Not a typical flamenco sound and a hint to the listener that this probably isn’t a traditional flamenco but yes, a modern view of the style.

Enters the piano a few seconds later. With the trombone on the bottom, the piano on top with high notes, and the flamenco guitar in the middle, the three instruments make a beautiful sonic sandwich.

A mellow melody is gradually introduced by the trio, along with occasional cymbal sounds. Still, the strumming and tapping of guitars always have a slight tension to them. Suddenly, the tension is released as the full band enters, with a Latin rhythm recognizable as flamenco, accompanied by a shoe-tapping sound, along with another surprise: an electric guitar. There is a clash between traditional and modern sounds in the music now, and I find it very appealing.

As the song continues, tension is built and released with more and more shoe tapping and stomping until the apotheosis.

It was very interesting to see how flamenco is approached in a new way. It was entertaining to watch the piece’s sudden changes in sound dynamics that are intended to be interpreted by a dancer and add drama to the performance.

item.title: Research point 1.0 – Renaissance madrigals
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643) Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary…
item.content:encoded:
Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643)

Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary who marked the transition from Renaissance to Baroque music.

Until the age of forty, Monteverdi worked primarily on madrigals, composing a total of nine books. In about four years, Monteverdi completed his first book of twenty-one madrigals for five voices. Overall, the first eight madrigals show the massive development from Renaissance polyphonic to baroque monodic styles.

He wrote L’Orfeo, one of the earliest operas in the history of music, an innovative work that remains a part of today’s orchestra’s repertoire. Additionally, he has written sacred music.

Orlando di Lasso (1532 – 1594)

Lasso was a Franco-Flemish composer. With more than two thousand compositions to his credit, he was a prolific and versatile author. This collection includes all genres of his day, secular and sacred, including the mass, secular chanson in several languages, Latin motets, hymns, and madrigals. When he held the position of Kapellmeister at the Munich court, at the end of his life, he cultivated sacred music with a special dedication.

He is considered the chief representative of the mature polyphonic style of the Netherlands school, along with Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina. At the end of the 16th century, he was one of the most famous and influential musicians in Europe.

Regarding his madrigals, which he penned while living in Rome, his style was clear and concise, and his tunes were memorable.

Comparison between Orlando di Lasso’s Matona, mia cara and Claudio Monteverdi’s Ah, Dolente Partita

The main reason I chose to compare these two madrigals is their contrasting themes. Lasso’s one is a jovial, lighthearted, and almost mocking monologue between a German soldier and a supposedly Italian woman. Contrary to Monteverdi, his lament is a sombre recognition of death in late life.

From the very beginning, these contrasting themes are evident. Matona, mia cara begins with all four voices in an F Major chord and in a fast tempo. The song develops with a mostly homophonic texture and a very marked rhythm, especially in the “Don, don, don” section. 

Ah, Dolente partita opens with only two voices in unison, singing a long, high E. The two voices stay in unison until bar 4 when they drift apart. As a result, it sounds very sorrowful and enigmatic. As the other voices enter, they do so timidly and not simultaneously. Only in bar 15 do all five voices sing together. However, just after that, in bar 16, the top two voices become silent. This creates a variety of aural experiences that convey the theme of lamentation.

Monteverdi’s madrigal has a more polyphonic texture than Lasso’s. Consequently, Ah, Dolente partita has a richer sound ambience, but Matona, mia cara has a stronger rhythmic mark. 

As a final contrast, I would like to mention the melodic shape. In Lasso’s madrigal, there are some upward and downward lines, with a lot of repetition of the melody, so it could be sung in a group with a dance-like feeling. Monteverdi’s melody, however, tends to move downward or remain flat, which is most evident towards the end, as if the music is taking small steps toward death.

References

Arnold, Denis Midgley. “Claudio Monteverdi”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 28 Mar. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Claudio-Monteverdi. Accessed 16 September 2022.

Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. “Orlando di Lasso”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 10 Jun. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Orlando-di-Lasso. Accessed 16 September 2022.

MORTENSEN, B., 2009. Recording Reviews – [Claudio Monteverdi: Madrigals]: “Flaming Heart”; “Fire and Ashes”. Choral Journal, 50(5), pp. 60-61. Accessed 16 September 2022.

fhunrichse, 2008. King’s Singers – Madrigal History Tour – Matona mia cara, YouTube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TPlb2jKCCQI . Accessed September 16, 2022.

item.title: Listening to Oscar Peterson – Hymn To Freedom
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points…
item.content:encoded:
I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points out that when you think about jazz names, Petterson’s is not the first that comes to your mind (Johnson, 2022).

Until today, I was unaware of Oscar Peterson’s name or work. Therefore, I decided to listen to “Hymn To Freedom”, a song featured in the article.

Oscar Peterson was born in Montreal, Canada on August 15, 1925 and grew up in a family where music was required of all five children. At the age of seven, he was able to play trumpet and piano. In his teens, he was already a prodigy when he became the star attraction of Canada’s renowned big band, the Johnny Holmes Orchestra (Peterson, 2003), and he was just 20 years old when he made his first trio recordings for RCA.

As a result of his musical genius, he was able to play with and alongside many jazz legends of the era, including Ella Fitzgerald, Roy Eldridge, Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker, and Billie Holiday (Johnson, 2022).

From 1959-1965, he formed and played with the Oscar Peterson trio with Ray Brown on bass and Ed Thigpen on drums, becoming one of jazz history’s most celebrated groups. Jazz historian Alyn Shipton explains one of their strengths as “Peterson’s skill at promoting group interaction marked the beginning of a seismic shift in piano trios.” (Hansen, 2014).

During the 1960s, there was racial segregation throughout the United States and Canada, and Peterson suffered a lot of racism when he toured with the Oscar Peterson trio. However, the experience of touring all over the world and especially his experiences in the south of the United States and observing the approach Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took to peaceful protest, led him to write his most influential work, the “Hymn to Freedom” (Small, 2021).

People all over the world quickly embraced “Hymn To Freedom” as the anthem of the Civil Rights Movement when it was written in 1962. A timeless and relevant piece, this song has been played at many major events around the globe.

This song’s main melody captured my attention from the first listen. The song reminded me of a gospel song infused with blues and jazz. 

In terms of structure, Peterson plays the melody four times before going into his solo, then returning to the original melody one last time. I believe this is an effective way of structuring a hymn, since the first four times he repeats the melody with almost no variation. As a result, the listener is able to engage with the melodic intention of the song. The piano solo builds upon the previous chord progression, but it is melodically much more unique than those first four repetitions, creating some interest. He concludes the solo with an apotheosis, but then the original melody is played softer, calmer, bringing peace to the listener’s heart.

My favorite part of this melody is the contrary motion technique, in which both voices go in opposite directions. While I’m still trying to figure out why I find it so pleasing to hear, I think it’s because it constantly creates a broader range of sounds. This makes it bigger and more interesting as a way of moving to the next part.

References

item.content:encoded:
I must admit that I didn’t know who Gesualdo was until today, so I had to do some research about the composer.

A Prince who composed secular madrigals, sacred vocal music, and instrumental music, Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa (c 1566 – 1613) published six books of madrigals and three books of sacred pieces during his lifetime. He was also notorious for brutally murdering his wife and lover in bed. In addition to this cold-hearted murder, many depraved tales have been told about Gesualdo’s mental health. Through these stories (whether true or not, it’s up for debate), we can trace a psychological portrait behind the composer whose work represents the culmination of Renaissance music at the end of the 16th century.

His harmonic language is still considered daring and extravagant today because it incorporates elements of the late Italian madrigals, characterized by sound experimentalism. He used complex chromaticism in a way that was extraordinary for his time. This would not be heard again, or even hinted at until Wagner, Schoenberg and Stravinsky took it to new heights.

This idiosyncratic use of chromaticism was not only an attempt to break the rules, representing his era in which Mannerism was emerging as deliberately disruptive but also had a rather specific objective: word painting.

As an example, when the subject of Amor, pace non chero of his 1st Book of Madrigals calls for his lover, he uses consonance and long notes (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

But in Mille volte il moro of his 6th Book of Madrigals, the Morte (death) is described with uncontrolled polyphony and highly dissonant intervals (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

It’s interesting to see how the technical complexity and themes changed from one book to another during his short life. The polyphonic tradition of the Renaissance dominates the first two books, while harmonic experimentalism dominates the third and fourth books. The last two, however, are characterized by more chromatic and dissonant writing, typically associated with mature composers. Considering the themes, his first two books are more simplistic, whereas his last two books are more dramatic in depicting themes of torture, pain, sadness, and death.

It surprised me to find that although we see Gesualdo as an avant-garde musical genius of his time, some people consider him conservative.

“As conservative as it was possible to be in this time. Monteverdi was the radical, the new. There is a very curious letter from the poet Guarini, in which he says he prefers Gesualdo to the modern style because he is ‘so far from the hardness of Monteverdi.’ For Guarini, Gesualdo is so nice, so easy! Exactly the opposite of what we now think.”

(Ross, 2011)

Even though other contemporary composers experimented with new sonorities and pushed further the boundaries of what music could be, I believe Gesualdo was one of the leading composers of the late Renaissance. While developing polyphony, a better sense of structure and rhythmic order, he explored contrasting emotions (like in Dolcissima mia vita) and influenced composers hundreds of years after his death.

References

Ross, A., 2011. Gesualdo. Alex Ross: The Rest Is Noise. Available at: https://www.therestisnoise.com/2011/12/gesualdo.html [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Burton-Hill, C., 2014. Gesualdo: Glorious music and grisly murder. BBC Culture. Available at: https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20130905-a-16th-century-musical-badass [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Garbuio, R.L. & Fiorini, C.F., 2015. “amor” e “morte” Nos Madrigais de Carlo Gesualdo: Um estudo sobre o desenvolvimento da escrita musical e textual. Per Musi. Available at: https://www.scielo.br/j/pm/a/rfCGr7VrcVTbmsczxX8YTsn/ [Accessed September 14, 2022].
